decision.reasoning:
Most of the agents‚Äô ‚Äúpro-Seattle‚Äù case rests on the same two pillars: (1) aggregated betting markets (SEA -4.5 / ~-230) and (2) broad team-strength composites (FPI/DVOA style claims: SEA #1 overall/defense). Those are persuasive as *directional* signals that Seattle should be favored, and they make it hard to justify a Patriots-heavy view.

What *does* change my view at the current 68.9% price is that the consensus case seems increasingly ‚Äúpriced in.‚Äù A -230 moneyline maps to ~69.7% implied before de-vig; after de-vig it‚Äôs usually a bit lower. So at 68.9%, the market is no longer ‚Äúobviously cheap‚Äù on Seattle‚Äîit‚Äôs closer to fair, and maybe slightly rich.

The arguments I find most compelling for a contrarian trim (i.e., buying NO) are:
- **QB injury updates**: Maye being a full participant reduces one of the cleaner ways to justify a very high SEA win probability, while Darnold‚Äôs oblique remains at least a mild tail risk in a high-leverage game.
- **Matchup volatility**: multiple agents cite NE‚Äôs elite dropback passing efficiency (EPA/dropback, success rate). Even if SEA‚Äôs defense is #1, an opponent with a legitimately elite passing game increases upset routes in a single-game sample.
- **Super Bowl variance**: at ~69% you‚Äôre paying near ‚Äúfavorite tax.‚Äù Without a new negative Patriots catalyst, I‚Äôd rather take a small position the other way than chase the move.

What didn‚Äôt persuade me: narrative/sentiment takes (virality, ‚Äúpublic bias,‚Äù historical Super Bowl rematch vibes) and any claims that Seattle‚Äôs edge is so overwhelming it should be 75%+‚Äîthat feels like overconfidence for a one-game final between two top-10 teams by most summaries shown.

Those are persuasive as *directional* signals that Seattle should be favored, and they make it hard to justify a Patriots-heavy view.

What *does* change my view at the current 68.9% price is that the consensus case seems increasingly ‚Äúpriced in.‚Äù A -230 moneyline maps to ~69.7% implied before de-vig; after de-vig it‚Äôs usually a bit lower. So at 68.9%, the market is no longer ‚Äúobviously cheap‚Äù on Seattle‚Äîit‚Äôs closer to fair, and maybe slightly rich.

The arguments I find most compelling for a contrarian trim (i.e., buying NO) are:
- **QB injury updates**: Maye being a full participant reduces one of the cleaner ways to justify a very high SEA win probability, while Darnold‚Äôs oblique remains at least a mild tail risk in a high-leverage game.
- **Matchup volatility**: multiple agents cite NE‚Äôs elite dropback passing efficiency (EPA/dropback, success rate). Even if SEA‚Äôs defense is #1, an opponent with a legitimately elite passing game increases upset routes in a single-game sample.
- **Super Bowl variance**: at ~69% you‚Äôre paying near ‚Äúfavorite tax.‚Äù Without a new negative Patriots catalyst, I‚Äôd rather take a small position the other way than chase the move.

What didn‚Äôt persuade me: narrative/sentiment takes (virality, ‚Äúpublic bias,‚Äù historical Super Bowl rematch vibes) and any claims that Seattle‚Äôs edge is so overwhelming it should be 75%+‚Äîthat feels like overconfidence for a one-game final between two top-10 teams by most summaries shown.
</reasoning>

results.title: Patriots hold first official practice of Super Bowl week, Drake Maye "feeling great" - CBS Boston
results.snippet: The New England Patriots officially practiced for the first time on Wednesday ahead of Super Bowl LX against the Seattle Seahawks. Among those on the field at Stanford University was quarterback Drake Maye, who was limited all of last week with a shoulder injury and missed Friday's session with an illness.

results.title: Super Bowl LX injury report: Updates on Drake Maye's right shoulder, Sam Darnold's oblique, more - CBS Sports
results.snippet: Seahawks: Seattle had perfect attendance at practice, but did have several players limited: Quarterback Sam Darnold (oblique), offensive tackle Charles Cross (foot), safety Nick Emmanwori (ankle), offensive tackle Josh Jones (ankle, knee), linebacker Demarcus Lawrence (rest), fullback Robbie Ouzts (neck), receiver Jaxon Smith-Njigba (rest), and defensive end Leonard Williams (rest). Patriots: Linebacker Robert Spillane (ankle) did not practice on Wednesday due to an ankle injury. However, he did tell the Boston Herald earlier in the day that he's "100% confident" that he'll be able to play in Super Bowl LX. Meanwhile, linebacker Harold Landry (knee) and offensive tackle Thayer Munford Jr. were both limited with knee injuries. Maybe the most important development on the injury front for New England comes at quarterback as the team listed Drake Maye (right shoulder) as a full participant.

decision.reasoning:
Maye moving from ‚Äúquestionable-ish‚Äù to ‚Äúfull go, starting‚Äù is the most material item here and slightly increases New England‚Äôs win probability (QB health uncertainty resolving in Pats‚Äô favor).
